list.title: module:skinkjs/dom
list.description:
Document Object Model (DOM)

Tools to help find and create page elements (HTML, etc).

ℹ️ Step-by-step instructions are available for users new to HTML or JavaScript.

What's a DOM?

The "Document Object Model" is all of the HTML tags and other elements like ::after or list bullet points.

If you're confused, don't worry. The following pages will help explain:

  1. What is the HTML DOM? (w3schools)
  2. The Document Object Model (DOM) (MDN)

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.appendAll
list.description:
Attach all elements in iterable to element.

Example

appendAll(document.body, [
     tag('h1', 'Title'),
     tag('p',  'An example use case.')
]);

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.copyElementHTMLToClipboard
list.description:
Attempt to copy the source of a given element or query selector result to the clipboard.

⚠️ Experimental

This may do the following in the near future:

  • fail with exceptions
  • replace the < and > characters in attributes (see {@link module:skinkjs/dom.getElementHTML|getElementHTML})

Example

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", {
     const {copyElementHTMLToClipboard, query} = skink.dom;
     const buttonArea = query('#buttons');

     // This is called a "delegated" event listener:
     // * The #buttons container handles click events for buttons inside it
     // * This is more efficient than putting a handler on every button
     buttonArea.addEventListener("click", (e) => {
         const target = e.target;
         if(! target.classList.contains("button")) {
             return;
         } else {
             copyElementHTMLToClipboard(button);

             // You may want to replace with nicer UI
             alert("Copied button!");
         }
     });
});

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.getElementHTML
list.description:
Get the source of a passed element or selector query.

The {@link module:skinkjs/dom.copyElementHTMLToClipboard|copyElementHTMLToClipboard} function may be of use if you need to get started quickly.

Example

const {getElementHTML} = skink.dom;

function alertSourceFor(eltOrQuery) {
    const src = getElementHTML(eltOrQuery);
    alert(`Source for ${JSON.stringify(eltOrQuery)}\n${src}`);
}

alertSourceFor('#your-id-here');

Tip

This function may begin replacing characters in attributes starting in September of 2025:

Character Replacement
< <
> >

This is a security-related change affecting:

  • HTMLElement.outerHTML
  • HTMLElement.innerHTML

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.nest
list.description:
Attempt to nest the given elements within an existing node or query result.

Example If we have the following HTML:

<ul id="results-list"></ul>

This JavaScript code will populate the list with cat and dog item.

const {nest, tag} = skink.dom;
 
nest('#results-list', [
 tag('li', 'cat'),
 tag('li', 'dog')
]);

The result will be equivalent to this HTML:

<ul id="results-list">
     <li>cat</li>
     <li>dog</li>
</ul>

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.query
list.description:
Convenience wrapper around Document.querySelector().

Example

const {query} = skink.dom;

const specialNode = query('#special-id');

if(titleHeading === null) {
  console.log("Couldn't find #special-id!");
}

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.resolve
list.description:
Returns at most one element as either the result of string query or the passed element.

  1. If elementOrSelector has a tagName attribute, it will be treated as an HTMLElement
  2. If it is a string, it will be treated as a selector string

Example

const {resolve} = skink.dom;

const titleHeading = resolve('h1');

if(titleHeading === null) {
  console.log('Couldn't find heading!');
}

list.title: module:skinkjs/dom.tag
list.description:
Create a tag, optionally with the given contents.

Example

// Usage in non-module form from skink.min.js
const {tag, appendAll} = skink.dom;

const tags = [
  // Create an empty tag. 
  tag('h1', 'Title here'),

  // Create a paragraph with nested values.
  tag('p', [
     text('Multiple values are '),
     tag('strong', 'permitted!')
  ])
];

// Remember to append the elements to show them!
appendAll(document.body, tags);

list.title: module:skinkjs/iteration
list.description:
Iteration helper functions for common tasks.

ℹ️ Step-by-step instructions are available for users new to HTML or JavaScript.

Technical Overview

The helpers in this module are generally composed of:

  1. An inner generator function
  2. An outer validation wrapper

The functions you call return the generator after validating input.

list.title: module:skinkjs/iteration.MismatchedLengths
list.description: This is raised by {@link module:skinkjs/iteration.zipStrict|zipStrict()} and other {@link module:skinkjs/iteration|skinkjs/iteration} tools

list.title: module:skinkjs/iteration~DigitLike#advance
list.description: Advance the dial by n steps in either direction defaulting to 1.

list.title: module:skinkjs/keyed
list.description:
Keyed Access

Helpers for keyed objects (arrays, etc).

ℹ️ Step-by-step instructions are available for users new to HTML or JavaScript.

These are available at skink.keyed if you need external versions of methods.

list.title: module:skinkjs/operators
list.description:
Operators

Operators akin to Python's operator module.

ℹ️ Step-by-step instructions are available for users new to HTML or JavaScript.

list.title: skink
list.description:
The global skink object is exposed for non-module users.

ℹ️ Step-by-step instructions are available for users new to HTML or JavaScript.

It holds a namespace object equivalent to each module.

Module Namespace equivalent Unpacking example
{@link module:skinkjs/dom} skink.dom const {tag, query} = skink.dom;
{@link module:skinkjs/iteration} skink.iteration const {range, enumerate} = skink.iteration;
{@link module:skinkjs/operators} skink.operator const {add, subtract} = skink.operator;
{@link module:skinkjs/keyed} skink.keyed const {pop, shift} = skink.keyed;

Brief Overview

For full instructions, see the step-by-step guide.

To use items in JavaScript:

  1. Find their name in the module doc (i.e. {@link module:skinkjs/iteration|iteration} or {@link module:skinkjs/dom|dom})
  2. Unpack it via destructuring

For example, to use the {@link module:skinkjs/iteration:range|range} function:

const {range} = skink.iteration;

To use items from {@link module:skinkjs/dom|skink.dom}, the approach is the same:

const {tag} = skink.dom;
